title: Daniel Haberman
text:
Daniel Haberman (1933–1991) was an American poet, translator and graphic designer. Haberman was instrumental in founding the <a href="American%20Poets%27%20Corner">American Poets' Corner</a> at the <a href="Cathedral%20of%20St.%20John%20the%20Divine">Cathedral of St. John the Divine</a> in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> and was the Cathedral's first Poet-in-Residence, from 1983 to 1986. In 1988 he and his wife, pianist <a href="Barbara%20Nissman">Barbara Nissman</a>, moved from New York to a farm in the <a href="Allegheny%20Mountains">Allegheny Mountains</a> of <a href="West%20Virginia">West Virginia</a>, where he lived until his death.
Early life and education.
Haberman was born in New York City in 1933, the son of Benjamin Haberman, a typesetter, and his wife Sadie (Daisee) Ballin. He attended the <a href="Walden%20School%20%28New%20York%20City%29">Walden School</a>, <a href="Carnegie%20Mellon%20University">Carnegie Mellon University</a>, and the graduate school of <a href="New%20York%20University">New York University</a>. He was educated in the second-hand bookshops of <a href="Manhattan">Manhattan</a> and by two years of study with <a href="Edward%20Dahlberg">Edward Dahlberg</a>.
Poet.
Haberman published two volumes of poetry in his lifetime, "Poems" (Art Direction Book, 1977; 2nd edition, 1982) and "The Furtive Wall" (Art Direction Book, 1982), the latter with etchings by <a href="Jan%20Stussy">Jan Stussy</a>. A collection of his verse, "The Lug of Days to Come" (John Daniel and Company, 1996), with a foreword by <a href="Guy%20Davenport">Guy Davenport</a>, was released posthumously.
Three of Haberman's poems ("Morning on the Orient Express," "The Sky in an Auburn Haze," and an untitled poem) appeared in the Spring 1984 issue of "<a href="Southern%20Review">Southern Review</a>".
Composer <a href="Irina%20Dubkova">Irina Dubkova</a> wrote a <a href="song-cycle">song-cycle</a> titled "The Lug of Days to Come", setting to music six of Haberman's poems.
Translator.
Haberman's translations of <a href="Archilochus">Archilochus</a>, <a href="Erinna">Erinna</a>, <a href="Praxilla">Praxilla</a>, <a href="Antipater%20of%20Sidon">Antipater of Sidon</a>, <a href="Zenobius">Zenobius</a>, and <a href="Gaetulicus">Gaetulicus</a> were done in collaboration with <a href="Marylin%20B.%20Arthur">Marylin B. Arthur</a>. Their translation of "<a href="Erinna">Erinna</a>'s Lament to Baucis" was published in 1993 in "The Norton Book of Classical Literature", edited by <a href="Bernard%20Knox">Bernard Knox</a>, and in "The Greek Poets: Homer to the Present", published in 2009 by Norton and edited by <a href="Peter%20Constantine">Peter Constantine</a>, <a href="Rachel%20Hadas">Rachel Hadas</a>, <a href="Edmund%20Keeley">Edmund Keeley</a> & <a href="Karen%20Van%20Dyck">Karen Van Dyck</a>.
Graphic designer.
Haberman designed 16 editions of <a href="William%20Shakespeare">Shakespeare</a>; his edition of "<a href="The%20Tempest">The Tempest</a>" (Composing Room & Graphic Arts Typographers, New York, 1971) was named by the <a href="AIGA">American Institute of Graphic Arts</a> as one of the fifty best books of 1972.
American Poets' Corner.
In 1983 Haberman was asked to create an American Poets' Corner at the <a href="Cathedral%20of%20St.%20John%20the%20Divine">Cathedral of St. John the Divine</a> in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York</a>, and was the Cathedral's first Poet-in-Residence. He personally raised $20,000 for the engraving of the wall and monuments to the first writers elected for induction (<a href="Emily%20Dickinson">Emily Dickinson</a>, <a href="Walt%20Whitman">Walt Whitman</a>, and <a href="Washington%20Irving">Washington Irving</a>).
The "Service of Dedication" of the American Poets' Corner took place on May 7, 1984, and featured such diverse talents as <a href="Edgar%20Bowers">Edgar Bowers</a>, <a href="Walter%20Cronkite">Walter Cronkite</a>, <a href="Zubin%20Mehta">Zubin Mehta</a>, <a href="Barbara%20Nissman">Barbara Nissman</a>, <a href="Gregory%20Peck">Gregory Peck</a>, <a href="Michael%20Tree">Michael Tree</a>, <a href="Rosalyn%20Tureck">Rosalyn Tureck</a>, <a href="Robert%20Penn%20Warren">Robert Penn Warren</a>, and <a href="Paul%20Winter">Paul Winter</a>.
While serving as Poet-in Residence, Haberman drew up the original set of 13 Electors to the Poets' Corner, inviting the poets <a href="Daniel%20Aaron">Daniel Aaron</a>, <a href="Edgar%20Bowers">Edgar Bowers</a>, <a href="Joseph%20Brodsky">Joseph Brodsky</a>, <a href="J.V.%20Cunningham">J.V. Cunningham</a>, <a href="Guy%20Davenport">Guy Davenport</a>, <a href="Anthony%20Hecht">Anthony Hecht</a>, <a href="John%20Hollander">John Hollander</a>, <a href="Josephine%20Miles">Josephine Miles</a>, <a href="Ann%20Stanford">Ann Stanford</a>, <a href="Robert%20Penn%20Warren">Robert Penn Warren</a>, <a href="Eudora%20Welty">Eudora Welty</a>, and <a href="Richard%20Wilbur">Richard Wilbur</a> to be part of the voting to select two American poets to be honored every year. Marie (Mrs. Hugh) Bullock, founder/president of the <a href="Academy%20of%20American%20Poets">Academy of American Poets</a>, accepted the position of honorary chairman; Lyn (Mrs. Edward T.) Chase, a vice president of the academy and a trustee of the cathedral, became an elector ex officio.
Haberman was succeeded as Poet-in-Residence in May 1986 by <a href="William%20Jay%20Smith">William Jay Smith</a>, and continued to serve as an Elector of the American Poets' Corner until his death in 1991.
